awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Security Applications of DRAM Cell Decay Effects
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project develops ideas and designs that can be used to fingerprint or authenticate computer hardware, to generate cryptographic keys, or form basis of new security protocols, all leveraging the physical properties of the computer hardware.  Especially, the focus of this research is on commodity memories found in today's computers, and the work advances fundamental understanding of how the physical properties of memories can be used in computer security.  By focusing on hardware already present in commodity computing devices, the ideas developed in this research can be readily deployed. Through development of professional and educational activities, and interaction with international colleagues, this project also supports dissemination of research ideas to a broad audience.

To advance the hardware security research field, this research project explores the cell decay effects in Dynamic Random Access Memories (DRAMs) and applies them to the design of DRAM-based Physically Unclonable Functions (PUFs), as well as to development of new virtual proofs of reality and Physical Cryptography primitives, all based on commodity DRAMs.  Through design of a manual refresh approach, this research shows how the DRAM's properties can be measured even if DRAM is part of a commodity computer system and actively used by software.  Environmental impacts on DRAM are also evaluated and understanding is developed of how the environment affects DRAM-based security primitives.  In addition, this research tackles challenges such as theoretical and mathematical issues of developing error correction schemes for use with DRAM PUFs, or practical issues of accelerating DRAM PUF readout time.

por.por_cntn:
This research project developed ideas and designs that could be used to fingerprint or authenticate computer hardware, generate cryptographic keys, or form the basis of new security protocols, all leveraging the physical properties of DRAMs (Dynamic Random Access Memories) or other memory-related hardware components. The project also contributed to fundamental understanding how DRAM memories could be abused by attackers to spy on users, for example. The primary focus of this research was on commodity DRAM memories found in today's computers, advancing the fundamental understanding of how the physical properties of DRAM memories could be used in computer security. By concentrating on hardware memory modules already present in commodity computing devices, the security protection ideas developed in this research were designed to be readily deployable. Through the development of hardware security tutorials and other educational activities and interaction with international colleagues, the project also supported the dissemination of research ideas to a broad audience.

The intellectual contributions of this project were the numerous and focused on understanding security of DRAM memories and other memory related parts of the computer. The project resulted in novel designs of decay-based DRAM PUFs (Physical Uncloneable Functions) in commodity devices. The project developed fundamental understanding of DRAM decay properties and metrics that could be used for design and evaluation of PUFs. The project further developed novel Rowhammer PUFs in DRAM memories, turning ideas of Rowhammer attacks into a positive, security defense mechanism. The project also created new dynamic PUFs that leverage decay properties of DRAM, not found in other types of memory-related PUFs. The project resulted in applied ideas as well, such as deploying DRAM fingerprinting in cloud-based reconfigurable logic that uses DRAM modules. The intellectual contributions also extended to building fundamental understanding of how attackers could abuse DRAM. The project showed how adversaries can spy on users through measuring environmental properties of remote devices, such as temperature, through monitoring DRAM decay rates. Applied ideas of the research included designs for measuring DRAM decay rates in parts of DRAM modules while remaining parts of the same DRAM module remain active. The research extended beyond DRAM, exploring cache memories and their security vulnerabilities and developed defenses. The project supported in part research on novel cache attacks on LRU (Least Recently Used) cache replacement policy. The project also supported in part development of benchmark suite for testing cache’s vulnerability to attacks. Applied aspects of the project included development of cloud-based testing framework for using tens or hundreds of smartphone-type devices for evaluation of processor cache security.

The broader impacts of the work are the contributions to ensuring security of modern computing devices that use DRAM memories, which is majority of computing devices today. The findings of the project can educate students, engineers, and of how computer security can be improved through use of physical properties of DRAM memories. The findings also point to possible ways DRAM could be abused by adversaries, and the feasible defenses that should be deployed. DRAM PUFs and related research findings have potential to be readily deployed without addition of new hardware components, improving security while reducing cost to users. With more secure features such as developed in this project, we can ensure that computing devices are processed, increasing individuals’ and the nation’s resilience to computer threats.
